bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, September 23, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses the painting of McDowell, which is being planned by Wyeth, and describes Rankin's criticism of the Cornwell yellow fever painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, September 23, 1941
div1.opener:
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N. J.
September 23, 1941
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I hope you will pardon me for not answering your letter of September
15th at an earlier date. Mr. Withington and I met in Louisville on
the night of the 12th and drove to Lexington, Kentucky the next day.
Dr. Rankin was unable to see us Saturday but we employed our time
pleasurably and profitably by spending half a day in Danville at the
reconstructed home of Dr. McDowell and talking to a few people who
were interested.

We saw Dr. Rankin on Monday noon and then saw Dr. Arthur McCormack
and his wife on Tuesday in Louisville. Dr. Rankin would be happy to
see the popular version of the McDowell story painted, that is the
one in which the discontented local citizens sit around a tree with
a hang rope suspended over a branch while the operation proceeded.
However, for more exact information he referred us to Dr. McCormack.
Dr. Rankin proceeded to give us quite a lecture on the propriety of
having a non-regulation sun helmet on General Wood in the Yellow
Fever painting. He further pointed out that the General would have
had his congressional medal on, something he considered a very
important point. It is possible that we may have the original paint-
ing changed but it is too late to do anything about the plates, that
is the printing plates. Rankin seemed very anxious to have the sun
helmets taken off all three men who are wearing them as he said they
were not regulation and having been in the army for many years he felt
that the soldiers would not like them as they give the picture a
British complexion. We can see his point. On the other hand, we have
had no objection from General Kean or General Trubie both of whom were
there at the time.

In our interviews with Dr. McCormack and his wife we found that while
they were both much interested in the story and Dr. McCormack had done
a great deal toward raising the money to make the reconstruction of the
McDowell home possible, it was Mrs. McCormack that had really read
carefully on the subject. She, however, has done most of her work on
the story of Mrs. Jane Todd Crawford. Furthermore, Mrs. McCormack who
in a general way represents the women's auxiliary of the State of
Kentucky, being rather prominent in their affairs is violently opposed
to the lynching story which she says is a popular concept based on a
-2-
newspaper item which ran in Louisville many years ago, said newspaper item
having been written by a reporter who only wanted to fix up a good story
(Incidentally, she said she had ascertained through long research that this
reporter was a drinking man). Anyway, we surmised after two hours' conver-
sation that if we were to paint the popular version we would have a rather
well organized small group in Kentucky who have made a serious study of the
McDowell story right on our necks. Of course, we knew in advance that both
William Allen Pusey and Dr. Schachner who wrote the authoritative books on
McDowell both laughed at the story.

The upshot of the matter is that we will have Mr. Cornwell submit sketches
to several of these parties in which the dramatic moments picked out by
Dr. Pusey are represented, namely, the time at which Dr. McDowell visited
Mrs. Crawford in her home and obtained her consent to perform the
operation. Frankly, we don't believe there are any Henchs in Kentucky.
We would like to win Dr. Rankin's support to this editorial angle and
because he is something of a hero to Kentuckians and of course is
nationally known, it would be very nice if we could interest him in making
a little speech on the subject when the occasion arises, that is when the
picture is unveiled. So much for our contacts in Kentucky.

I was much interested in your report on the exhibition of paintings in
Madison, Wisconsin. Mr. Withington's report was essentially the same. He
attempted to get the store to take the fur coats out of the windows in
which the paintings were shown but with no success whatsoever. The point
that upset me most was the fact that the Medical Society did not have any
cards in the window to tie the exhibition up with the Society. The store
got all the credit for having the paintings and of course the purpose of
the exhibition is to give the local medical society who arranges for their
exhibition a bit of nice publicity.

Your story about the spectator who admired the window dresser was very
amusing.

I called Dr. Bauer as soon as I returned and asked him for a quotation on
25,000 reprints of the Hygeia article. I have not heard from him yet as
he said it would take some time to get the figures. I have asked to have
the reprints bound in blue paper so that they will make a nice looking
pamphlet and of course the same insert which is being used in Hygeia will
be tipped in. I anticipate that they will not charge us more than about
$15.00 or $16.00 per thousand for the bound reprints. Incidentally, we
are setting aside 5,000 for you which we consider a wise investment.

I have not had the opportunity to write Dr. Kahn as my secretary has been
sick now for almost ten days. I am glad to know that we were not wrong on
the method of using the test tubes and I shall send him this information.

The large reproductions are now off the press and are being framed. In-
cidentally I received a very nice letter from Miss Agramonte, a copy of
which I am enclosing.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, George Kellogg George A. Kellogg/ecs--Encl.
(P.S. follows)
-3-
P.S. Withington and I are making arrangements to have one of our men stay
with the paintings continously. That will be his only job - to travel with
them and arrange for their display. We think we have just the man for the
work. The troubles in Wisconsin came as a result of our not having anyone
there who knew what to do. Confidentially, we expect to just take one of
our smart, young detailmen who is unmarried and doesn't mind traveling
continuously and train him to be a traveling showman to cooperate with
local medical societies and institutions that are exhibiting the paintings
and see that the local society gets good publicity in the local papers and
actually gets real value from having the exhibition. Wyeth can only get
their money's worth out of the project if the pictures accomplish something
for the local doctors. When any exhibition is over we want the officers
of the medical society to be able to say that the exhibition of the Wyeth
pictures did a fine job for them. John Wyeth & Brother, Inc., in that
way will get dividends on dollars invested.
G.A.K.
